awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Towards Communication-Cognizant Voltage Regulation and Energy Management for Power Distribution Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Power distribution systems have continued to witness transformation in generation, consumption, and operational landscapes. Sustainability concerns are driving widespread integration of distributed renewable generation, plug-in hybrid electric vehicles, demand-response programs, and advanced metering infrastructure. These emerging devices and resources have the potential to greatly improve operational efficiency and reliability with the aid of advanced communication, sensing, and computation capabilities. Nonetheless, distribution systems are equipped with limited cyber resources in communication, sensing, and computation. By and large, their supporting cyber infrastructure is, and continues to be, less reliable and less ubiquitous as compared to that for the bulk power transmission grid. Challenged by this status quo, this project will develop novel coordination algorithms for operating distribution systems, which are cognizant to the limited availability and low quality of the underlying communication and the cyber infrastructure in general in the foreseen future. Successful completion of this project will promote increased deployment of distributed energy resources and cyber infrastructures in distribution systems. In addition, results from this project will be shared with industry in order to have an impact on practice. Project results will also be employed in the development of educational materials for middle school students and a new undergraduate course.

This project will develop communication-cognizant algorithms with provable performance in terms of stability, efficiency, and reliability. The algorithms will be designed to be robust to different imperfect communication scenarios, such as limited bandwidth, link failures, and communication delays, with graceful degradation performance.  One key feature of the algorithms is the coordination between the coupled physical distribution systems and cyber communication networks. Building upon mathematical tools from optimization and control, the team plans to revitalize the algorithmic design by leveraging physical measurements to complement the cyber communication networks for accelerated information diffusion. The research project consists of four cohesive thrusts: (1) Developing and analyzing algorithms that use no communications; (2) Designing distributed algorithms to approach global efficiency; (3) Enabling robust designs against imperfect communication; and (4) Unifying theoretical analysis with real-world implementations, and coordinating the design of cyber-physical architectures. The project will deliver: (i) a suite of algorithmic tools under various realistic communication scenarios that incorporate models of key system components; (ii) performance analysis for the developed algorithms in an online and uncertain implementation; and (iii) algorithmic validations in a realistically represented numerical environment. The research will fulfill the objectives of advancing the operational goals of power distribution systems while allowing for practical communication architectures and algorithmic implementations under a more versatile and low investment environment.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
The power distribution grids are witnessing continued transformations in the operational landscape with increasing deployment of distributed energy resources (DERs) such as distributed renewables and energy storage. The goal of this project is to investigate the problem of coordinating the heterogenous DERs at the grid edge under the practical limitations of communications available in distribution grids. In particular, the problem of maintaining the system-wide voltage under dynamic, uncertain environments constitutes as the major DER coordination task of this project.

The main results of this project are a suite of efficient, decentralized DER coordination algorithms that are adaptive to various rates of communications. Our algorithmic design builds upon the physics-based model of distribution grids (accurate approximation of multi-phase power flow model), and neatly incorporates the real-time feedback of voltage measurements. This way, possible modeling mismatches due to power flow approximation and parameter error can be mitigated, improving the robustness and adaptivity of the algorithms. Furthermore, these algorithms can deal with the following scenarios of communication availability: i) no real-time communications from DERs; ii) peer-to-peer DER communications without centralized operator; and iii) varying rates of communications between centralized operator and DERs. For each scenario, the convergence and (sub-)optimality performance has been analyzed, allowing to better understand the value of communications to the effectiveness of DER coordination. Notably, we have further considered the scenario of a locally connected communication network, where real-time communications are only possible within sub-groups of DERs. Graph-theoretic analysis points out that the subgroups of DERs can still reach an equilibrium using local voltage feedback information, yet the equilibrium condition can strongly depend on the connectivity, or the lack thereof, of the underlying communication graph.   

Inspired by the main theme of this project, we have further addressed the increasing dynamics of distribution system resources with developing new real-time decision-making solutions. First, we have investigated the real-time enhancement of the optimal power flow solution, considering the fast, dynamic data streams of system-wide measurements. We have been particularly interested to utilize these measurements to empower the voltage stability enhancement capability of DERs. Second, we have pursued the operational problem for dynamic, aggregated resources like electrical vehicle charging demand. We have constructed an efficient representation of the problem state-space model for developing data-driven reinforcement learning method. All of our algorithms have been successfully validated on real-world systems based on accurate power flow modeling.

Broader Impacts: Results from this project have contributed to the continuous transition of power distribution grids in integrating dynamic, heterogenous resources at grid edge while addressing the critical limitation of cyber infrastructure. They have been shared with academia, national labs, and industry partners through presentations and research collaborations. These dissemination efforts have led to real-world impact for attaining sustainable and efficient energy delivery, as well as shed light on the design of general cyber-physical systems. The research results have also been integrated into the PI's education and outreach activities including teaching, research advising, and promoting pre-college STEM education.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Hao Zhu

Images (1 of )
  • The algorithmic design uses a flexible updating rule in accordance to the rates of information availability under possible communication link failures, where the local voltage measurements are always available for correcting the decision q.
    Hao Zhu
    Public Domain
    Hao Zhu
    proposed hybrid design for coordinating distributed resources
  • During the period of communication outages, the proposed hybrid design (HVC scheme) can effectively mitigate voltage deviation while the existing distributed optimization based design is unable to adapt to a varying operating condition.
    Hao Zhu
    Public Domain
    Hao Zhu
    Numerical performance improvement of the proposed hybrid design
